characters: WE MOVE THROUGH THE ONE-WAY MIRROR INTO -
AN IMAGE FLASHES ACROSS HIS EYES
CHICKEN, HOT DOGS AND CORN SIZZLING ON AN OUTDOOR GRILL.
AND NOW, EVERYTHING HAPPENS AT ONCE
WE MOVE THROUGH THE ONE-WAY MIRROR INTO --
A7 HALLWAY NEAR POWELL'S OFFICE AT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New immigrant families stand in ticket lines next to body pierced teens. Dozens of languages fly through the air, n of them English. This is the crossroads of the world for down and out, hard luck and New York on 5 dollars a day c Witness to it all is a grey~bearded BLACK HOMELESS VETERA sits with his prosthetic leg parked beside him.

dialogues.speaker: VET
dialogues.text: Dollar fo' a homeless vet. Help out a homeless vet. (as a student with a duffel bag hurries past) C'mon, li'l man - I fought the war with your Daddy. P'nam Pen. Y'all ain't paid me for this leg yet! A young, SWEDISH COUPLE with backpacks catch his eye.

dialogues.speaker: VET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yo, Swiss Miss - let's see that smile! How ‘bout you Fritz? I know y'all got a wallet in that backpack. Freeloadin’ mother- (stops midword, as an Asian family with many bundles passes by) Heyyy - Jackie Chan! Shanghai Noon! I take traveler's checks. Yeah, arrigato to you, too! He pauses for a moment, with a curious expression, as som else catches his eye ... A BEAM OF HAZY SUNLIGHT shines down through one of the hi arched windows of the terminal building ... onto a MAN. Or an apparition. The VET squints, closely ... as the FIGURE seems to emerge from the sunlight. Dark, wraparound SUNGLASSES mark his placid face. He wears cord pants, a faded denim shirt. And though he carries no lugg his cheap canvas shoes look like they've got some miles o them. We will come to know this "man" as PROT. For now, he just stands there, taking everything in with the fascination o tourist, as the crowd bustles around him. Suddenly - in front of the rest rooms ~ TWO YOUNG THUGS bump into a middle-aged RUSSIAN WOMAN. On wrenching her SUITCASE away - the other knocking her down

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she screams for help, they run off - shoving past PROT and into the crowd. Prot watches them f a moment ... as if unsure whether to register anger or caution. Then, he turns to the woman. She is on the ground, dazed and sobbing, while everyone s quickly around her. Prot approaches her. The vet keeping a careful eye on him Prot stops, standing over the woman. She looks up at his glasses, stocky shoulders, fearfully. But as he holds his hand out, and offers a smile ... her fear is strangely al

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Here, let me help you. The CRACKLE of WALKIE-TALKIES interrupt, as two TRANSIT C hurry over.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Hold it right there!

dialogues.speaker: VET
dialogues.text: Oh, man ~ he ain't done nothin'. The OFFICERS nevertheless regard Prot with suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Step away from her.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: This woman is hurt.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND OFFICER
dialogues.text: Ma'am, what happened? The woman struggles with limited English.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Eh - take bag ... eh - hit.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND OFFICER
dialogues.text: Who took your bag and hit you? This man? The vet shakes his head at the cops, sorrily.

dialogues.speaker: VET
dialogues.text: No, no. Couple a punks. They ran ran eff. Y'always comin' around too late - askin' what? Where? How? This brother just tryin' to help her.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/15/00 (Goldenrod) 3+.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: be

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (one eye on Prot, trying to explain, unable to) Yes - he ~ he ~ he. The lst officer speaks into his radio:

dialogues.speaker: AST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Four-eight, this is Romano. Robbery and assault victim with facial wound at West Forty-Second entrance, (then, to Prot) Sir, I'd like you to just stand right there, answer a couple of questions for me. Standard Procedure. The 2nd officer carefully handcuffs Prot. Prot gives both officers a curious smile, as if discerning a foreign cust

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Are you travelling somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I've arrived. My travels are over for * the time being. *

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Where's your luggage?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Luggage? * iST OFFICER * Your bags. *

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I don't require luggage. * The officer takes a good, hard look at Prot. His sunglass canvas low-tops, general appearance. Outside, an ambulanc pulls up with a whoop. An M.T. enters the Station, starts tending to the woman.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: {pressing Prot} Do you have a ticket? (off Prot's look) * A train ticket. A ticket stub. *

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I didn't arrive by train. *

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/15/00 (Goldenrod) 4.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Then, what are you doing in the train * Station, sir? .

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: It seems a likely place to begin. The officers glance at each other, this is beginning to s familiar.

dialogues.speaker: VET
dialogues.text: Name! Rank! Serial number! All you * got to give 'em, my man! *

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Freddy, chill. * {back to Prot) * Would you remove your sunglasses for * me, please?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I'd rather not. of course, the warned me about the photokinetic energy from star G-643, or as you would call it, the sun, but, I mean, wow! Your planet is really bright! bee eH A wry understanding moves across both officers' faces.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: I see ... . (into his radio) West Forty-Two. We have an E.D.P.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to Pret, politely) I'm going to ask you to come with us.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (polite in return) Certainly. As Prot is led away, the VET Straps on his leg and gets himself up. For some strange reason he feels an affinity Prot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Prot is led outside. His dark glasses take in the nois chaos of New York, with amazement. The VET hobbles out the doors, as PROT is placed in a POL CAR. The lst officer comes back over to the vet.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: You see this fella come out of a gate?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/15/00 (Goldenrod) 4ar,

dialogues.speaker: A2 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The vet leans closer, with import, to the officer:

dialogues.speaker: VET
dialogues.text: Didn't come from no gate. Brother just ... came outta nowhere. You know what I'm sayin'?

dialogues.speaker: B2A
dialogues.text: c2 Rev. 07/20/01 (2nd Salmon) (Replacement Scenes) 5.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The officer considers the vet a moment, smelling the alco on his breath.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yeah, Freddy. I know what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam. Metal sheet on road clatters as POLICE CAR speeds it... pan down through grill over bridge of POLICE CAR speeding underneath us. Pov from inside police car of metal lattice work on bridg stxrobing past. The reflection of a skyscraper ... becomes a SYRINGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establish hospital. Powell walks to entrance. * INT. MANHATTAN PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE (MPI) — DAY c2 LOOKING OUT THE WINDOW of DR. POWELL'S OFFICE onto the TR on 112th and Amsterdam below. Horns honk, drivers cuss. Superimpose: One Month Later

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I - I don't want to go outside ... Because, you know ... there’s things ++. that can kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. MARK POWELL, who has been staring out his window, clo it, shutting out the noisy world. ERNIE sits in a comfortable chair. Pale, nervous, he wear rubber gloves and speaks through a surgical mask.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: (relieved) Thank you. JI mean you breathe all those chemicals out there. Not to mention the cosmic rays and that - that West Nile virus - and the other one! The new airborne pigeon disease nobody wants to talk about!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 07/20/01 (2nd Salmon) (Replacement Scenes) SA*,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: POWELL, late-forties, takes his seat. He rolis a gold Montblanc pen in his fingers as he listens to Ernie cover his tedium with the studied patience of a man who's been his job a long time. Perhaps, too long.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Pigeon disease - I've heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: And - and another thing that's been bothering me - is the food. The cafeteria serves lukewarm food - full of germs! You need to do something about that, Doctor Powell. Heat is Bbe only thing that kills the germs. eat!

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Point taken. {pretends to seriously jot it down on his pad) We'll look inte that xight away. In the meantime ~ I want you to start taking your medication again. (reminding him) It's liquid now, so you can't choke on it. It'll help you Sleep. And you need to sleep, Ernie. Sleep is good. Ernie shakes his head vehemently.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Sleep!? You ~ you - you know what happens when you sleep? You can swallow your tongue - or - or fall out of bed, break your neck. (slumps in the chair, a hopeless knot of worry) Or ... or burst a blood vessel in your head. Never even wake up ... Powell's BEEPER goes off, much to his relief. He glances the clock on the wall, Presses a buzzer by his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Is ... is our time up? Powell addresses the fear on Ernie's face with a rushed s

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Only for today, Ernie. He barely waits for the attendant, SIMMS, to come in and escort Ernie out, before speaking into a hand held RECORD

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Patient one-five~six, Ernie Coleman. Suggest slightly increased dosage of anafronil.  Rev. 02/22/01 (2nd Goldenrod) 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell gets his jacket from the coat rack. JOYCE TREXLER sits at her computer. Pictures of her husba a policeman, and her grown children grace her desk. As we as a knit affirmation that reads: "There is a Rest_ of Yo Life." She keeps her eyes on her screen, her voice pleasa

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TREXLER
dialogues.text: Two calls. Your wife, bring home a bottle of wine. And Doctor Chakraborty ~ transfer from Bellevue he wants you to take a look at. Joyce hands him a file.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Great. Who is it this time, Jesus or Joan of Arc? Mrs. Trexler just raises an eyebrow to him. After fifteen years as his secretary, she's used to the sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TREXLER
dialogues.text: Doctor Chakraborty didn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell navigates through NURSES, SOCIAL WORKERS, POLICE transferring homeless psychotics... Head Nurse BETTY MCALLISTER, an unflappable woman, blocks path with a clipboard. Beside her, two ATTENDANTS hold a disheveled SCREAMING MAN.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: Can you admit this patient, Doctor Powell? They found him on the West Side Highway. Auditioning to be somebody's hood ornament.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Why is he screaming?

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: He thinks if he stops the world will end.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Not before Saturday night. I have Knicks tickets. McAllister gives him a wry eye, as he signs the admitting paper. Just as he's about to escape, she hands him a seco clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ee  4

dialogues.speaker: AS
dialogues.text: Rev. 07/20/01 (2nd Saimon) (Replacement Scenes} 8.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: When he calms down I want to sit down and talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: And this is to boost Mrs. Archer's Zoloft.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I don't want to boost Mrs. Archer's Zoloft. I want Mrs. Archer to get out and get some exercise.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: With who ~~ her personal trainer? C'mon, Doc. I'm short-handed here. Powell looks at the clipboard. Reluctantly writes the prescription. As yet another clipboard is slipped to him.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: Ed. Halidol. He bit Navarro's thumb off, yesterday!

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I know, Betty. But Haldol's not going to curb his appetite. He hands her back her clipboard, leaves her with a wink.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Maybe we should all start screaming. CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell enters hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell releases a harried breath against the closed door then notices he shares the elevator with an ATTENDANT and PATIENT. The patient, SAL, a big, puggish, middle-aged ba man gives Powell an evil eye.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You stink! As the attendant waits with Sal, Powell obliges him with brief smile. As he exits, saying:

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Have a nice day, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon) ge,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell moves past a ONE-WAY GLASS. Sees Prot in his room observaton, apparently looking at himself in the glass. Something about Prot -- perhaps simply his arresting appearance ~~ stops Powell. He stops to look at him. It i as if Prot is looking directly at him. * Powell stops a puzzled beat. Prot smiles. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON several X-RAYS and MRI SCANS of a CRANIUM as the snapped into place by DR. CHAKRABORTY, the chief Clinical Physician. Harvard School has not dulled his affable Indi accent. He turns as Powell enters.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Did they change out the one-way glass in the observation room?

dialogues.speaker: CHAKRABORTY
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Because there's a guy in there -~ [ could swear he was watching me. What's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: CHAKRABORTY
dialogues.text: He arrived at Bellevue a month ago, suspicion of hallucinogenic intoxication - but found negative for substances of any kind. Blood values, EKG ~ all normal. No sign of concussion, no brain tumor, no temporal lobe epilepsy ~ no indication of organic abnormality whatsoever. However, after one month, amnesia and delusion have persisted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over his bifocals.

dialogues.speaker: CHAKRABORTY
dialogues.text: He claims to be...not human. (clarifying) ‘ A visitor from another planet. tee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell sits on a stool, studying the new transfer's FILE.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: They administered thorazine on this guy for three weeks at 300 milligrams a day ~ and he was unresponsive. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon) 9A*.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looks up at Chakraborty, skeptical) How the hell can you be unresponsive to 300 milligrams of thorazine? It's impossible. Chakraborty looks over his bifocals, at Powell.

dialogues.speaker: CHAKRABORTY
dialogues.text: That's why they've sent him to you. Powell takes in Chakraborty's look for a Moment. Then, wi a frown, looks back down at the FILE.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Terrific. No I.D. No Missing Persons reports matching his description ... Then, baffled, Powel] lifts up from the file ... a sheet notebook paper, handwritten in pencil, of the most astoun alien-looking HIEROGLYPHICS.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: CHAKRABORTY
dialogues.text: He had it on him. Powell can't help let out a wry chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 02/22/01 (2nd Goldenrod) 10.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Let's hope extraterrestrials qualify for Medicaid.

dialogues.speaker: A7 HALLWAY NEAR POWELL'S OFFICE AT
dialogues.text: Navarro and Simms escort Prot to Powell's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell speaks into his RECORDER. The file in front of him

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Patient two eight seven ... (checking the name) calls himself... "Prot." His door BUZZES. Powell leaves the RECORDER running, gets from his desk, He straightens his tie, puts on a professi face.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in. Two attendants, NAVARRO and Simms escort ... PROT ... int room. He wears the same denim shirt, corduroy pants and canvas shoes as we saw him in before. He smiles, from behind his dark glasses, at Powell. Navarro, a big, bearish Puerto Rican, reassures Powell wi nod, anda bandaged thumb's up.

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: This one's gentle as a Pussycat, Doc, Powell, nevertheless, keeps a careful eye on Prot, who re standing ... as Navarro and Simms exit, closing the door. Powell motions to one of two CHAIRS.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Won't you have a seat. PROT . Have a seat, curious expression. As they both slowly sit, Powell probes Prot's sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Is it... too bright in here?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Quite bright - one of the first things a visitor to your planet notices.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 02/22/01 (2nd Goldenrod) 1OA*.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Ah hah. Well, let me introduce myself. I'm -

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ll.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Doctor Mark Powell. Chief of Clinical Psychiatry of the Manhattan Psychiatric Institute. Powell regards him a moment, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Good. You know where you are. (has to check the file again) Now ...°'Prot' is it?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: {correcting him, Pronouncing it like "goat') Prot. POWELL ; I see. Well ... Prot. We're here to talk. I'm going to ask you some questions, If you feel like answering them, you may, (as genuinely as he can) I want you to feel comfortable. Prot reaches for a bowl of FRUIT on the desk beside them.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Thank you. May I? Powell considers the request, a little wary.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Please. Prot picks an APPLE, admiring it. PROT - . Red Delicious you call this variety. My favorite. Powell watches as Prot takes a bite with a rapturous sigh POWELL ; I'd like to begin by asking if you know why you're here?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Of course. You think I'm crazy. Powell stares, as Prot devours the apple, core and all.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From behind smile. (2)

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: We prefer to use the term 'ill.' (forcing a smile) Do you think you are ... ill?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: A little homesick, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (careful) Really? And where is home? the dark wraparound glasses comes a celestial

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (studying him) Kay~packs?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Capital K- hyphen - capitals P-A-x. Roughly translated into your Roman alphabet. (starting in on another apple) K-PAX is a planet. Powell contemplates the conviction with which this was ju said. When Prot suddenly laughs:

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't worry - I'm not going to leap out of your chest!

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Ch, I'm not worried. It's just that I'm only familiar with nine planets.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (between bites) Actually, there are ten, but that doesn't matter - I'm not from your solar system. K-PAX is about a thousand of your light years from here. Near what you call your Constellation LYRA.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (raising an eyebrow) Quite a ways. I'm curious ... how did you get to Earth?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: That's somewhat difficult to explain.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Try me. Prot pauses from eating, trying to think of how to put it

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: It's a matter of harnessing the energy of light. (sees Powell is not going to get it) I know that sounds - crazy ~- to you. You beings are eons away from discovering light travel. Powell watches ... as Prot raises a hand so that his fing touch the hazy SUNLIGHT filtering through the window blin

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You travel at the speed of light?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Oh, no. We can travel many times that speed, various multiples of c. (laughs) Otherwise, the trip here would have taken me about a thousand years, now wouldn't it have? Powell tries to couch his puzzled amusement with seriousn

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What if I were to tell you - that according to a man who lived on our planet, named Einstein, nothing can travel faster than the speed of light. Prot looks at Powell, with an astute smile.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I would say you misunderstand Einstein, Doctor Powell - may I call you Mark? (getting chummy) What your Einstein said, Mark, was that nothing can accelerate to the speed of light because its mass would become infinite. epnstein Said nothing about entities alread traveling at the speed Of Tight, or faster - at tachyon speeds. Powell stares back at him, at a complete loss.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Tachyon ...

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Entities traveling faster than the speed of dight are called tachyons. You can look it up.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (getting a little peeved) Thank you, I will. Prot watches Powel] jot down something with his Montblanc

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I detect a note of skepticism, Doctor Powell.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Not at all. It's just that - you speak English so well, I'm amazed.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: It's not a very difficult language to zearn. You should try speaking wxljqz- pit. Powell puts his pen down, even more amazed at the guttura clicks and sounds that just came out of Prot's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: i'm a little confused. Maybe you could explain to me, how it is -asa visitor from space — you look so much like me ~ or any other Earth person?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (patiently) Why is a soap bubble round? ( flexed. } perplexedly Why is a boap bubble round?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: For an educated person, you repeat things quite a bit, Mark. A soap bubble is round because that is the most energy-efficient configuration. Similarly, on this planet I look like you ~ on K~PAX, I look like a K-PAXian. Powell has had just about enough of this.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: One more question - Prot. {glancing at the clock) Why did you want to come to Earth?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (finishing apple #2) Pure curiosity. I had never been to a Class BA-3 planet.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Class ... BA-3? Prot regards Powell with a patient sigh.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Early stage of evolution, future uncertain. STAY ON POWELL, as he feigns a look of understanding.

dialogues.speaker: ASA
dialogues.text: Rev. 07/20/01 (2nd Salmon) (Replacement Scenes) 15C~D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell enters house. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell comes in, carrying a bottle of wine. He leaves briefcase in the front hallway. The house is well-to-do, art on the walls, a grand piano facing a woodsy patio. Powell's daughters, NATALIE, 6, and GABBY, 9, sit trancel in front of their PlayStation on a giant TV screen. Powell scratches their heads, in greeting...

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Gabby, you do your homework? Gabby nods, barely looking up. While Natalie presents her father with a grin, displaying a new gap in her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: I lost another tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 07/17/01 (2nd Buff) (Replacement Scenes) 16.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Good. Maybe the tooth fairy will come tonight. He leaves her with that, and a little smile, heads on tow the kitchen. Natalie, watching him go.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: There is no tooth fairy. There's just you and Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell carries the wine into the kitchen. Where RACHEL PO is busy taking the components of a reheated dinner from t oven, and placing it on the kitchen table which she has s for two. She is a vibrant woman, and it's clear she has t pains with the meal.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Kids already ate. She stops to kiss Powell. A deep, committed kiss.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Train was late. He turns to the counter, rolls up his sleeves, goes about uncorking the wine.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ok OE tee  Rev. 07/17/01 (2nd Buff) (Replacement Scenes) 17.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Six-fifteen didn't leave the station until almost six-thirty. {pours two glasses, remarking to himself, with half amusement) Should've caught the nearest beam of light. She finishes tossing the salad, regards him, curiously.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You caught what?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Never mind. He places a glass of wine in front of her, with a smile. really filled it to the top.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: How was your day? She watches him gulp down half his glass of Pinot Blanc a turn his attention to the mail on the counter.

dialogues.text: I wonder if you might tell me more about your home?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: What would you like to know?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Well ... did you have a job on K~PAX?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (finding this funny) No one has a "job" on K-PAX. Really, Mark, is it that difficult to understand? On K-PAX, if something needs to be done, you do it.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: There must be jobs people don't want to do. Hard labor, cleaning public toilets? I mean, that's only human nature,

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: There are no humans on K~PAX.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Ah, I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Besides, there's nothing that needs to be done that is really unpleasant. Look, you defecate, don't you? Powell gives him a ridiculous look.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Not as often as I'd like.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ee ee ek bk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 01/09/01 (Ivory)

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Do you find it unpleasant?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (finding this even more ridiculous) Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Do you get someone to do it for you?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I would if I could.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: But you don't, and you don't think twice about it. You just do it. And it does have its rewards, right? Powell resists the temptation to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Okay, look, let's move on. Do you have family on K~PAX?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 32a. ig oF ek eR oe eee

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Prot finishes the papaya, licks his fingers. Sensing Powe is up to something.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Things are not the same on K-PAX as they are on Earth, Mark. We don't have "families" as you know them. The idea of a 'family' would be a non sequitur on our planet - and most others, I might add.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (tries to see past the smile) Are you saying that ... as a child, you had no home to go to?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Exactly, now you've got it.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: In other words, you never knew your parents.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: On K~PAX, children are not raised by their biological parents, but by everyone. They circulate among us, learning from one, then another ...

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (pressing him) What about brothers and sisters?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: No one on K-PAX has more than one child. There is little reason to, since the average lifespan of a K-PAXian is a thousand of your years.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Do you have a child?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (quickly) No.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Do you have a wife waiting for you back on K-PAX? Prot releases a tedious breath, as if not caring for the direction of this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon)

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Mark, Mark, Mark. You haven't been idistening. We don't have marriage on K-PAX - no husbands, no wives, no families ~ get it? To put it more correctly, the entire population is one big family.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I see. What about a societal structure then? “Government?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: There is no need for one.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What about laws?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: No laws, no lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Well then how does one know what's right and wrong on K-PAX?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (as if this were a stupid guestion) Every being knows what's right and wrong.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: But what if someone did do something wrong? Committed a murder? Rape?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, Marko. Most humans subscribe to the policy of "an eye for an eye," "a life for a life." Most of your religions are famous for this formula, known throughout the Universe for its stupidity. Your Christ and your Buddha had a different vision, but nobody paid any attention to them, not even the Christians and Buddhists. So, no. On K~PAX beings do not kill other beings, but if they did there'd be no punishment. Apparantly this is impossible for Earth beings to understand, but it's the secret of life, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: No crime, brutality, violence on K-PAX?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: You humans. Sometimes it's hard to imagine how you've made it this far. Crime is less popular than sex, even. There's simply no need for it.
19 oe ee oe

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Powell remains staring at Prot ... feeling the thread of reality slipping away again ...

dialogues.speaker: CHICKEN, HOT DOGS AND CORN SIZZLING ON AN OUTDOOR GRILL.
dialogues.text: A swing hangs from a giant spruce. Natalie and Gabby are being chased by their cousin, JOSH, 10, around the big ya Powell, lost in thought, watches over the grill. As Rache Comes up, snaps her fingers in front of his face, playful Then gives him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Where were you just now? Powell just gives her a frustrating smile, and puts the c on a platter, handing it to her.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Kids! Wash up! Powell knocks back his glass of wine, leaves it by the gr And follows her across the yard, with a second Platter he with hot dogs and chicken - almost tripping over SHASTA, a golden retriever, who is b chased under the back porch.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Josh, don't tease the dog! He sets the platter down on a PATIO TABLE ~- at which sit sister ABBY, late-thirties, and her husband, STEVE, a bur bearded fellow.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we are. Napkins are opened, and pungry "Ooohs" evoked. The kids j them at the table. As they all sit down and start eating, Abby and Rachel eye each other, before Abby addresses her rother.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: i'm not taking sides here but we're going to kidnap you to get you up to the Cape.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (to Abby, but with a smile to Rachel) I see my wife has been talking.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rachel gives him a mischievous little smile back.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) Steve, how was the drive from Princeton? Steve wipes corn off his mouth, his voice a friendly Tenn rawl. s Not too bad.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We stopped off to see Michael, Powell meets Abby's eyes. There is tension between brothe and sister.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: That was nice of you. Quite a detour.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It was his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I know it was his birthday. I sent him a card with a nice, big check. As usual. Abby exchanges a glance with Rachel, who stays out of it. Abby io0ks back at her brother, lets a beat Pass, can't h erself:

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You know, it wouldn't kill you to pick up a phone once in a while and talk to your own son, Powell catches a look from his two young daughters,

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Abby. By the way, I put him through Dartmouth - he knows how to pick up a phone, too.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (trying to diffuse things) I was thinking of inviting him for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: He goes to his mother's for Christmas. He won't come here.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: How do you know? When was the iast time you asked him?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Am I on the couch, here, sis? Abby says no more. And Powell does not give her the Satisfaction of taking this any further. They continue eating. After a moment, Powell turns to Steve, thoughtful

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Steve, I have an unusual favor to ask.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What can I do you for, Doctor B.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Well ... I have a patient who seems to know something about your field.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You have a patient who's an astronomer?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (puts her arms proudly around Steve's girth) I beg your pardon, Full Professor of Astrophysics as of next month.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Steve ~- congratulations!

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Steve,

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you. (then, curious} So who's this patient of yours?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (wipes corn off his hands) He claims to come from a planet he calls "K-PAX."

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: KayPacks? The KIDS laugh, repeating the funny name several times.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Says it's a thousand light years from here, near the constellation Lyra.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Big head, green? About this high? (puts his hand at 3 feet I think I know the guy. As they all laugh, Powell remains mildly serious.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: No, no - he's very convincing. Rachel, Abby, Steve, and the kids stare at him. Powell views them, with an embarrassed laugh.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I mean - of course, he's human! He's just ... the most convincing delusional I've ever come across. (to Steve) And I'd like to prove to him that this - K-PAX - is a figment of his imagination. (pours himself some lemonade) If I can do that ... then, maybe I can find out who he really is.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Am I hearing right? The great Doctor Powell needs help with a patient? Powell just gives his sister a tired look. Steve scratches his bushy beard.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Constellation Lyra, hmmm. Sure - I can give you a whole bunch of questions to ask your fella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell hurries down the haliway with Nurse McAllister. MCALLISTER . I don't know what's wrong. All his books and papers and everything are spread out over his desk, like always. But he's just ~ They get to the ONE-WAY MIRROR, look into the DAY ROOM, t HOWIE, just sitting calmly, gazing out a window.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 21 22 Rev. 02/06/01 (2nd Yellow)

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ~ sitting there. Powell stares at the peaceful Howie, in utter amazement.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Did someone change his medication?

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: No. I gave him his regular, Anafranil, point two hundred fifty milligrams.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Well, something's wrong with him. An obsessive compulsive doesn't just sit there looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell enters. Slowly approaching Howie, he notices th Howie's glasses are, for the first time, clean. them, Howie remains gazing, with fixed purpose, cut the w

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Howie?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Doctor Powell. Powell leans down to Squint out the window with

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Howie ... what are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: The bluebird.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (takes a moment with this) The bluebird?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Bluebird of happiness. Prot told me to find the bluebird of happiness. Powell's expression changes.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Prot ... told you? And through him. Howie nods, his eyes not leaving the gardens and brick wa of the gated hospital grounds outside. Cc

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It's a task, the first of three. I don't know what the other two are, yet. He'll tell me. (smiles, proudly) If I complete all three, I'll be cured. Powell's look tightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrubs and flowers line the high, old brick walls. A foun bubbles. Attendants slowly walk patients along the paths. Ernie stands under a tree, taking deep breaths. As Prot Coaches him, reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Maintain breathing. That's it. You see? There are none of these "ammonia particles" you are worried about. For one thing, J would be able to see them - and I don't. Ernie, breathing, manages a nervous smile - then spies Po marching across the grass toward them.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Winged monkey at two o'clock. Prot turns, curiously, as Powell marches up.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Excuse us for a moment, Ernie. Ernie looks from Prot to Powell. Then, fearfully, up at t sky. He scrambles backwards across the lawn, up the veran steps, and into the refuge of the hospital. While Powell views Prot with an aggravated breath.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's one thing to take an interest in your fellow patients - it's quite another to make them think you can cure them! Prot regards Powell, baffled at his angry tone.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: You seem overly upset, Mark. To borrow a phrase from Raul ~ you need to "chill." (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (with a smile) For your information - every being has the Capability to cure themselves. This is something we have known on K-PAX for millions of years.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Listen to me! On this Planet, I ama doctor. You are a patient. ~

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Doctor - patient. Curious human distinction.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (in a burst of anger) It is not your job to cure Howie or Ernie or Maria or anyone. It's mine!

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Then, why haven't you cured them yet? As Powell stares at Prot, fishing for a reply -~ Prot carefully takes out several folded NOTEBOOK PAGES, h them to him.

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, here are the answers to the questions you gave me. TI hope you find them to your satisfaction. Powell, left with nothing to say, just takes the Pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve scratches his beard, mystified, as he looks over Pr NOTEBOOK PAGES. Behind him, we see a giant telescope and vast array of digital instruments and computers. He speak the phone:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don't know what to Say, Mark. This is ... pretty wild stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell leans back in his chair, with a confident smile.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Gibberish, huh? ‘  26 27 28 29 Rev. 11/3/00 (Blue) 43.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well ... not exactly. See ~ your patient indicates his planet "K-PAX" orbiting an eclipsing binary star system, Agape and Satori, near the constellation Lyra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell straightens up in his chair, skeptical, phone to e

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Okay, so he could have read about it somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That's the funny thing, Mark. Not really. You see ... except for my boss, Duncan Flynn, who's one of the foremost astrophysicists in the world, and maybe - two or three of his colleagues ~ nobody knows much about the possibility of planets in this star system yet. It hasn't even been reported in any journals. He looks around the observatory, lowering his voice into phone, with a shrewd smile:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me, honestly. Duncan put you up to this? You know, like a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAY ON POWELL - as he holds the phone. He attempts a lit daugh, unwilling to believe what he's hearing, then glanc into the outer office at Mrs. Trexler, who looks up from work at him, oddly.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: It's ... no joke, Steve. (then, grasping) You wouldn't happen to know of any missing astrophysicists would you? 26 27 28 29  30 31 32 33 34 Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon)

dialogues.text: Steve shakes his head, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Can't say I do. (then, seriously) But there's one or two aro who'd sure like to meet th yours.

dialogues.text: C.U. ON the back of the TAXI DRIVER'S HEAD ... IN THE REAR VIEW MIRROR - WE SEE PROT, flanked by Chakrab and Navarro. Powell is in the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the TAXICAB drives up, dwarfed by the six-story SPHERE gleaming wonder of glass and metal that faces Central Par

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter. The place is empty. The visitors have long departed. A giant mobile of the solar system hangs four stories high. There are meteorites, and displays of space exploration and giant, backlit PHOTOS from the Hubble -~ GALAXIES, NEBULAS, the now-famous GAS PILLARS at the edge the known universe. Navarro, amazed, never having seen anything like this him gives Prot a sly, little look.

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: This your neighborhood, huh? Prot takes it all in ... with a laugh of both wonder and familiarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell, a little anxious, shakes hands with the three astronomers Steve has brought. DUNCAN FLYNN, distinguishe white-haired, with a pipe - and two others, DAVID PATEL a STUART HESSLER. They wear the intense eyes of men who hav spent their lives looking to the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Thank you, gentlemen, for doing this.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor Powell. {holding up Prot's pages) We'd like to get to the bottom of these notes as much as you would.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I'll bring him right up.

dialogues.speaker: A37
dialogues.text: Se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Prot enters through the double doors, with Navarro and Chakraborty. We are in a HUGE, DOMED ROOM. Empty stadium seats all aro A formidable camera/computer projector rises from the cen of the floor. Navarro, amazed, has never seen anything like this himsel He takes a seat by the doors, with Chakraborty.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Letting Prot walk slowly ... toward a semi-circular confe table hooked up with two state-of-the-art FLAT-SCREEN MON at which sit Steve, Flynn, Patel and Hessler. The men stare at Prot, not really knowing what to expect. Powell quietly takes a seat by Chakraborty and Navarro. H catches Steve's eye, gives him a little nod.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It's a pleasure to meet you, Prot. Won't you ... have a seat. Prot looks around, takes the chair in the center of the r by the projector, facing them.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm ... Doctor Becker. This is Dr. Flynn, Doctors Patel and Hessler.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: How many doctors are there are on this planet? Steve laughs, looks at his colleagues. He likes this guy. Flynn motions to Steve, who walks over to the Planetarium console and presses a button. The lights go dim. And on t DOME above them all ... is projected ... an astonishing S OF STARS. It fills our senses, as if we are actually ther Chakraborty and Navarro lean back in their chairs. Navarr eyes now as wide as his mouth, as he utters:

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: Shit ... Powell looks from the stars to Prot ... As Prot takes his glasses off ... gazing up - and around the IMAGE ... with a wide, breathless smile ... anda laug of both wonder and familiarity.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (smiles at Prot) Feel at home? Flynn clears his throat, trying as hard as he can to trea Prot seriously.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: We have found your notes quite interesting ... Prot.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we'd like to ask you some questions ~ if that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Be my guest.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Good. Then I'11 jump right in,

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Make sure you can swim. Flynn attempts an awkward little laugh, looks at the othe By the doors, Navarro, amused, repeats "make sure you can swim" to Powell and Chakraborty, in case they didn"t get

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Yes, well. Let's start with this idea of light travel, shall we? What can you tell us about that?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (smiles) Nothing. The scientists give each other dubious glances.

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I told you, you'd blow yourselves up. Or worse, Someone else. You'd be surprised how much energy there is in a beam of light. They respond to this with tentative laughter. Steve takes over, being friendly.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, then, I wonder if you could show us how this light travel works.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: How about a demonstration? Powell's expression becomes uncertain. He catches a wary sidelong glance from Chakraborty.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (surprised) That would be ... fine.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Adios! Aloha! He sits there with a wide grin.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Steve views him with uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: When are you going to ...

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I'm already back. The scientists can't help let out a couple of belly laugh Steve regards Prot, shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Where I come from, that's called the fastest gun in the West routine.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: {imitates his Tennessee drawl, with equal candor) Well, I don't come from where you come from, Dr. Becker. More laughter. Powell has to smile, a bit sadly, as he regards Prot, see what a farce this is becoming. When Flynn attempts to be serious again, perusing Prot's notebook PAGES in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Prot, you've indicated in your ~ motes ~ that your planet K-PAX orbits the twin stars Agape and Satori near the constellation Lyra. Frankly, we're a bit mystified as to how you gained knowledge of such a Planetary system around these stars. At the planetarium console, Steve presses another button a huge INSERT OF A MAGNIFIED STAR SYSTEM APPEARS projecte against the dome of stars.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was taken from the Hubble. We computer enhanced it, based on Doctor Patel's readings from telescopes in Chile and Hawaii. It is the clearest picture we have of — (checks himself, regards his colleagues) ~ where you come from. What we'd like --- is if you could diagram on your lightpad, the orbital pattern your planet takes around this system.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (delighted) My pleasure. He gets up, goes over to the lightpad, picks up the stylu there. Unsure, he looks back at the scientists. They nod. Prot makes a mark on the lightpad over the projector. He looks up. It appears as a scribble across the STAR SYSTEM He shakes his head, erases it, then starts again, animate looking up to the stars with every mark he makes. The scientists lean back in their chairs with bafflingly amused expressions. But as Prot's scribbles take shape up ABOVE THEM ... thei expressions begin to change ... For there ... projected over the STARS ... emerges a coge detailed DIAGRAM of what looks like a 4-PLANET SOLAR SYST around the two brightest stars. Complete with a grid of ANGLES and FORMULAS of relative distances. Prot looks up, puts down the stylus, satisfied. Flynn, slowly, takes the pipe out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Steven ... could you input that ...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Already on it. Steve has the Princeton Observatory database on line. As maltiple STAR CHARTS and theoretical CHARTS appear on his MONITOR, he hurriedly inputs Prot's information from the Powell looks from Prot's diagram to the scientists, confu

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What - what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: {admiring Prot's work) Looks like the real thing to me. Flynn, Patel and Hessler get up from their chairs to crow around Steve's laptop.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Somebody want to tell me what the hell's going on? The scientists watch, agog, as the monitor displays an ex replica of Prot's solar system.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Prot observes them, with a knowing chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I take it my calculations help explain the perturbations you've been seeing in the rotation pattern of your binary star ~ but have been previously unable to explain. For a long beat, the scientists just stare at Prot, speec

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: How ... how could you know this? How could you ...

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Every K-PAXian knows this. Doesn't every school child on Earth know your planet orbits your sun in an ellipse? Flynn and his colleagues look at each other, stupidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prot sits waiting in the TAXI with Navarro and Chakrabort Powell and Steve stand on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What happened in there, Steve? I mean - he could be a savant. There are savants who have painted flawless copies of Rembrandts who couldn't even remember their own names. Steve, you don't believe this guy do you!? Steve, with a look toward the taxi, confides to Powell:

dialogues.speaker: _ STEVE
dialogues.text: I don't know what I believe, Mark. But, I know what I saw. Tell you what I'm going to do ... I'm going to computer generate a star chart of the night sky as seen from the position of this planet K-PAX. Ask your man to draw one from memory. Then send it to me. If his matches mine - I guarantee you the government would take him off your hands. Powell just stares, maddeningly, at his brother-in-law.  40 41

dialogues.speaker: A42
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/20/00 (Buff) Sl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell sits in the dark. With an empty Scotch glass. Gazi up, troublingly, at the sparse Connecticut stars. Prot's Planetarium DIAGRAM rests in his lap. He turns, to gaze at his wife through the glass doors ... She sits playing the piano very softly, as the kids are l asleep. He admires her back, her lithe beauty, the way sh tucks a strand of hair back and turns the music page. He gets up, comes into the ~-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel hears the patio door slide open, turns. They regar each other for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Don't stop.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: There's a key stuck.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: We'll have to get that fixed. He sits beside her on the bench. She shows him...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: G below middle Cc.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: That's probably an important one, huh.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: My old teacher -~ I've told you about her --

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Hilda.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Right. Powell smiles.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Hilda from the City Opera. With the yellow teeth and the cat with the stomach trouble. Who would fart in four/four time. Rachel laughs. Powell laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: With his tail going. Like a metronome.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Shut up. She was a very good teacher.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: As long as you like cats. Their laughter subsides. Rachel looks away from Powell fo introspective beat. Then turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She used to tell me, don't play the notes.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Don't play the notes?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. If you just play the notes, you'll miss it. They look at each other. On Powell,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon) 52a. INT. WARD 2 ~- DAY ROOM - Day CLOSE ON HOWIE. Seated at his post by the window. His eye suddenly widen. And a smile of immeasurable joy spreads across his face.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Bluebird... Ernie and Sal look up from a checker game. Russell stops muttering a Bible passage. Only Bess remains disintereste in front of the Tv. As Howie jumps out of his chair -~

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Bluebird!! He starts running from window to window -- jumping over tables, knocking over chairs.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Bluebird! Bluebird! AT THE NURSE'S STATION ~ McAllister spots him from the on glass. She hastens into the DAY ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: Howie? -He runs up to her, dances her giddily in a circle, over window. Where she looks out, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: Oh, my... He bounds out of the day room -- and down the CORRIDOR -- Shouting from ROOM to ROOM at the top of his lungs:

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Bluebird! Bluebird! Patients peek out of doorways with wide eyes and medicate smiles. BACK IN THE DAY ROOM ~ Ernie turns fearfully to Sal.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Do -~ do bluebirds bite?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: No, they don't bike, stinkhead!

dialogues.speaker: BACK DOWN THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Howie, like a barefoot dervish twirls up onto a windowsil He puts his face to the BARS -- shouting out, freely, euphoric, with all his might -- as sunlight kisses his fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING UP - from Howie's shouting face, and WIDENING ~ to in the other WARDS on the floors above. As pale FACES, so with shaved heads and hollow eyes come to the WINDOWS, lo out with suspicion and wonder ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navarro and Simms step off the elevator ~ into pandemoniu Patients running out of rooms, up and down the corridors, half naked, shouting "Bluebird! Bluebird!" Navarro whips the walkie-talkie out of his belt, speaks quickly into it:

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: Disturbance is on Two!  54. & 45 INT. CORRIDOR ~ IN A MINUTE 4s Powell barrels through two SWINGING DOORS and runs down t CORRIDOR, Chakraborty and the overweight Fleen trying to up with him. They hear CHANTING coming from down the hall

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What the hell? We FOLLOW THEM into the DAY ROOM ~— where the entire ward has erupted into an ecstatic chorus "BLUEBIRD, BLUEBIRD, BLUEBIRD!" Patients are crowded arou the windows, jumping up and down, some standing on tables get a better look. Fleen looks shaken.

dialogues.speaker: FLEEN
dialogues.text: It's mass hysteria ... Powell eyes him, ridiculously. Nevertheless, trying to ca sight of somebody, anybody, in charge.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Betty! What's going on? McAllister turns from the window. She knows it's silly, b ) she wipes a tear and smiles, pointing out.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: Look. Powell regards her bafflingly - when Howie suddenly grabs by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Doctor Powell! Come, see! Disinclined, Powell lets himself be led to the WINDOW - to see, indeed - a beautiful, common BLUE JAY. It flits, majestically, from tree to tree, chirping and pecking. Finally settling on a branch. As Powell gazes upon it, in profound astonishment - Ville now wends her way through the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: What's going on here, Mark? {craning her neck to see) What on earth is out there?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Just a blue jay ... » She gives him a nonsensical look.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: A blue jay? Powell opens his mouth to say something more. But instead looks from the window - around, slowly ~ witnessing the unbounded hope and excitement on every patient's FACE.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Just a blue jay. He turns ... catching sight of Prot, who stands observing the day room doorway. Their eyes lock for a moment. Prot smiles at him. And then ... Powell, to his absolute amazement, sees Mrs. Archer come into the day room! She looks around at the commotion with wide eyes, and the smile of a little girl. Taking hold of Prot'’s arm ... Then Ernie approaches Powell.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Doctor Powell, can we go outside and look at it? Powell takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You want to go outside, Ernie?

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: To look at it.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's go outside. Powell puts his arm around Exnie. As they head outside, h and Prot exchange a last look. On Prot,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAYING ON POWELL, as he stands with ail the other COMMUT on the Metro North PLATFORM, waiting for the 6:15 to Connecticut. Across the tracks on another platform, he watches a FATHER kid around with a young SON. They are obviously on their way to a ball game, both wear Mets caps. The father with a food cooler, the boy with a

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: First of all, Mark ... we make no distinction between ‘childhood' and adulthood’ on K-PAK - you can check your notes ... A fleeting, wistful look crosses Powell's eyes, as he wat father and son board a train. Prot's WORDS filling his he

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: On Earth, children are encouraged to Play all the time. That's because you believe they should remain innocent’ of their approaching adulthood for as jdong as possible, apparently because the latter is so distasteful ... Powell opens his briefcase, takes his CELL PHONE from its pocket. He ponders it. Then fumbles through his wallet fo a phone number.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: But on K-PAX, children and adults are all part of the same thing ... With indecision, he dials the number. Gets an annoying NO SERVICE BEEP. He moves back, up the crowded stairs. fries again. Hand over his ear.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: On our planet life is fun and interesting. There is no need for mindless games, either for children or adults. No need for dying, for escape into game shows, football, alcohol, or other drugs ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has the look of being just moved into. Milk crate furnitu an electric guitar and amp, bicycle hanging up on the wal A 21-YEAR OLD with a still boyish face looks up from the as the phone rings. He puts down his McDonalds dinner. His hair is cropped sh bleached. His eyebrow is pierced. The phone rings again. gets up, walks over to it, answers it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Hello ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell calls on pay phone at Grand Central Station.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Michael. Happy birthday. TI forgot to call.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Dad? Hey, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Good -- you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: That's good. How's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 02/06/01 (2nd Yellow)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Fine. I saw her 'bout a week ago. She asked about you.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Did she? Teli her I said hi. Listen, my train's about to leave. I just...wanted to say happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Take care. Thanks for calling.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Okay. You too.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: All right. ‘Bye, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: AND
dialogues.text: Sl
