dialogues.text: ee eee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 Rev. 11/14/00 (Green) 57. INT. WARD 2 - PROT'S ROOM — NIGHT A narrow bed and a small metal table are the only fixture Prot sits at the TABLE in front of his grilled WINDOW, hi glasses resting beside him. He looks up ... to a few STAR twinkling through the grill. PROT'S POV. The stars visibly move across the cloudy heav Their faraway light fills his face. He closes his eyes, concentrating ... and starts drawing DOTS, fast and furious, on the blank S OF PAPER in front if him. IN THE HALLWAY - Bess, roaming the halls, stops. In front Prot's door. Through its small window ... she watches him Her eyes silent, piercing.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: (whispering) I know who you are ... IN HIS ROOM - Prot stops drawing for a moment, as if sens her presence. Without turning around, he offers Bess a sm IN THE HALLWAY - Bess keeps staring at him. She doesn’t smile. But there is an intent belief in her quiet voice.

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the bluebird. 52  SB.

dialogues.speaker: AS4
dialogues.text: As Prot walks down the hallway. Maria stands there in a w nurse's cap and gloves. He greets her with palpable good cheer.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: How are we, today?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Just fine. Prot walks on, pointing a finger at Navarro, who points a finger back at him.

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: My man. A furtive Sal gets his attention, with a "Pssst." Curious Prot comes over. Sal glances up and down the hallway to m sure no one's watching, motions Prot into the ART ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patient artwork is all over the walls. Sal draws Prot clo keeps his voice low.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: About that light travel thing. I was wonderin' ... if you could maybe show me how to do that? (with desperation) I've put up with the stink in here for ten years. I sure would like to get out ... know what I'm sayin'?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Why have you stayed here so long, Sal, if this - stink - bothers you?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Ain't exactly my choice. My wife put me in here. Sal picks up a brush, pretends to paint just to look busy he makes his voice even lower, eyes searching for any pry ears.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, I was the doorman at the Plaza.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: The Plaza?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Hotel. Fifteen years. I opened the doors for some of the fattest cats in the world. Movie stars, financiers, politicians, the movers and shakers. You know the type. After fifteen years ... that's when I started to notice it ...

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (considers Sal, unclear) Notice what? Sal pulls him closer, expression changing, nose scrunchin

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: The smell ... the smell! (almost unbearable for him) God! What putrid, disgusting stenches! No one could smell a thing - except for me! I tried to tell people - I tried! But nobody would listen. Not even my wife. Not even my kids. (whispering now) That's why they put me in here. Because nobody wants to hear the truth! And this place ... stinks worst of all! He looks right into Prot's dark glasses, with a sense of camaraderie.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Except for you. That's why I knew ... you'd be able to help me, As Sal's lip trembles, Prot's own expression changes, as dwelling on Sal's plight. Then, his voice soothing:

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: You must smell the yort blossoms on my planet, in a gentle breeze. Very much iike your sugar plums. Now that is a sweet smell. Sal views Prot's smile, hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I'd like to smell that. I'd like to +--+ go there. To your planet.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I can only take one person back with me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sal stares at him. His tough, round face breaking into a thrilled, clandestine smile.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I read you, pal. Prot looks at him, sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Thanks, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prot sits, meditatively, in the garden. As Powell approaches, something clearly on his mind. He . observes Prot for a few beats, before Sitting down next t on the stone bench.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I had my weekly session with Sal today. “He says you're taking him to K-PAX. (lets Prot absorb this) In fact, I've heard from most of the Patients on Ward Two. They all tell me they're going to K-PAX. TI wonder if that's a wise thing to be promising patients in a psychiatric facility. Prot knits his brow, with a problematic sigh.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: No, no, no. I told them all very clearly. I would only be able to take one person with me when I return. Powell blinks, not sure he's heard correctly.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Return ...

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: No offense, Mark. I mean you've been very hospitable. Hospital - “hospitable” ~- get it? But my time here is almost up, and I can't wait to get back.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Back ... to K-PAX?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Where else?

dialogues.speaker: AS4
dialogues.text: 54  Rev. 07/30/01 (2nd Tan) (Replacement Scenes) 61-63A*.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You're planning to return to K~PAX.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: You are repeating yourself, Mark. Yes. I am planning to return to K-PAX. Powell sits there, at a momentary loss for words. He lets a flummoxed laugh.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You'll have to forgive me, this comes as a bit of a surprise. But - when are you ~ planning on - ?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Well, first, I have to take a short trip up to some of your north lands -- Greenland, Iceland, Labrador ~-- to complete my report. (consumes another strawberry) Then, I'll be departing on July 27th. Powell stares at him, stunned by the finality of these wo Trying to collect himself, he helps himself to a strawber

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Why - why July 27th?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Safety reasons. You see, I can go anywhere on Earth without fear of bumping into anyone traveling at superlight speed. But beings are coming and going from K-PAX all the time. It has to be coordinated -

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You're telling me you're “beaming” back to K-PAX on July 27th? Prot just turns back to the fountain, with a smile of certainty.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: At 5:51 a.m. Eastern time.

dialogues.speaker: BEO
dialogues.text: Rev. 07/30/01 (2nd Tan) (Replacement Scenes) 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell wakes up in the dark, with a gasp, heart beatin Rachel sits up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mark, honey, you were dreaming! She smooths his face, puzzled. He turns to her, still breathing hard. Then, suddenly, jumps out of bed, wrestle some pants, and hurries out of the bedroom. Rachel quickly puts on a robe, following after him -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mark. Mark, you're worrying me. ON THE LANDING - Natalie comes blearily out of her room, having been woken up, sees her father bound down the stai

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Where is Daddy going?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He just has an upset stomach, honey. Go back to bed. Natalie, not convinced, watches her mother bound down the stairs after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell turns on the desk lamp and rifles through the cassette TAPES - until he finds the one he wants. Rachel watches him, with mounting confusion. As he pops the tape into the machine, dons headphones, rewinding - forwarding until -

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Listen, listen - here it is! He unplugs the headphones, so she can hear. As Rachel listens, she keeps her eyes, disturbingly, on her husband His hair is wild, his eyes fixated.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: When did you arrive here on Earth?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Steve ... listen to me ... just sit on it... please ... I need ... I need a little more time ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell wakes up in the dark, with a gasp, heart beatin Rachel sits up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mark, honey, you were dreaming! She smooths his face, puzzled. He turns to her, still breathing hard. Then, suddenly, jumps out of bed, wrestle some pants, and hurries out of the bedroom. Rachel quickly puts on a robe, following after him -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mark. Mark, you're worrying me. ON THE LANDING - Natalie comes blearily out of her room, having been woken up, sees her father bound down the stai

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Where is Daddy going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just has an upset Stomach, honey. Go back to bed. Natalie, not convinced, watches her mother bound down the stairs after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell turns on the desk lamp and rifles through the cassette TAPES - until he finds the one he wants. Rachel watches him, with mounting confusion. As he pops the tape into the machine, dons headphones, rewinding — forwarding unti. ~

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Listen, listen - here it is! He unplugs the headphones, so she Gan hear. As Rachel listens, she keeps her eyes, disturbingly, on her husband His hair is wild, his eyes fixated.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: When did you arrive here on Earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon) on ur CONTINUED: Bec

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Four years and nine months ago. Your years that is. Powell turns off the tape, looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Four years and nine months ago! That will be five years to the date, on July 27th! (seeing she doesn't understand) The date he's leaving to go back to

dialogues.speaker: K-PAX
dialogues.text: She's more worried about her husband, than trying to understand.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mark ... what is the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: {impatient with her) Don't you see, Rachel? * Natalie and Gabby now join her in the doorway, viewing th father with uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mark ... it's two o'clock in the morning. What is this patient doing * to you? He looks at her, looks at his daughters, as if the answer evident.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: He's telling me that five years ago on July 27th - something terrible * happened to him...some horrible trauma. *

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of? *

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: That he's planning to do something violent. To himself or someone else. I've got to get to him before that date. ee EK Powell's family just remain staring at him...  60 Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon) 6SA*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunny day, the trees brilliant green. A flag flies abov the front portico. Abby helps Rachel spread a tablecloth across a long picnic table. Steve pops a beer, smiles at day. Natalie runs barefoot around the yard with festive streamers. Powell stands at the top of his drive, looking, up and do street. As Gabby comes up to him, with a skeptic's brow.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Is the spaceman here yet?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Hush! Do not call him that. A CAR comes down the tree-lined street.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here they are ... everybody just act like yourselves, be normal. (Natalie and Josh squeal past him) Kids - settle down! As the CAR pulls into the drive, Rachel views it, cautiou from the yard. She comes over to her husband. Keeps her e on it, as it rolls toward them ... RACHEL . Gabby, why don't you take your sister in the house ...

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Why, is he going to zap us with his laser gun?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Just do it, young lady. Gabby gives both her parents a pitiful look. As the car approaches the head of the drive ...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't believe I agreed to this.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I've tried everything else. I want him to spend the Fourth of July with us, see if a normal family environment might bring something out of him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (an eye to him) Since when did we become a normal family?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Rach - please.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I just feel ... uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Not to worry. Mrs. Trexler's oldest is a high school varsity wrestler. And Betty McAllister's husband is a black belt. So, I think we're covered. Rachel puts on her best face, as the CAR comes to a stop A big, muscle~bound 18-YEAR-OLD OLD with a buzzcut steps first, followed by Mrs. Trexler.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Joyce, how good to see you! (they hug) And can this be Danny? Next out of the car are Nurse McAllister and her husband, a real New York Italian.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Betty - I don't think I've ever seen you out of uniform.

dialogues.speaker: MCALLISTER
dialogues.text: That's because I look like a Weight Watchers “before” shot. This is my husband, Dominic.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: Dom. Trexler and McAllister look into the backseat of the car, beckoning someone else out. A beat. Slowly ... hesitantly ... Prot climbs out of the car. He stands there. The trees reflected in his dark glasses. Rachel stares at him. As Natalie, Josh and Gabby run up, grabs their hands tight, to hold them back.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Wow, he looks like Data!

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: {rolling her eyes} Oh, that's right, embarrass him. Powell shushes them, furiously.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Welcome, Prot. This is my wife -

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (smiles at her) Rachel. Thank you for inviting me here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rachel remains staring at his dark glasses. She doesn't k whether to extend her hand. instead, she just smiles back

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: How do you do. Suddenly - the DOG runs out from under the house, and bar straight for Prot.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Shasta! No! Shasta! But to Powell's surprise, Shasta wags her tail, flattenin herself against Prot's leg as if he were a trusted friend In the next instant, to everyone's surprise, Prot falls t ground, rolling, playing, even barking with Shasta. Abby eyes Steve, who comes up behind her, utterly amazed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: {mutters to her) Damn dog's never liked anyone. Before anyone can stop them, Natalie and Josh run over to in the fray.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL AND ABBY
dialogues.text: (simultaneous, horrified) Kids! Prot sits down on the grass, moves the kids onto his knee He regards them, happily, and with gentle fascination. Powell signals Rachel and Abby with his eyes, to relax.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: (to kids) Watch this. Prot begins to "talk" to Shasta in remarkably accurate do whelps. Even more remarkable, Shasta starts howling back.

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She says she does not like it when you hide her favorite shoe or sneak up on her left side - because she can no longer hear well in that ear. The kids stare at him, in open-mouth disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: No way. Even Gabby the skeptic has to laugh in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Prot resumes "talking" to Shasta - Powell is puzzlingl amused. He catches Rachel's eye - she is not so sure, Dom, watching Prot, gives McAllister a look that says "th guy is the biggest wingnut I've ever seen." She cautions with a nudge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grill sizzles. Everyone is seated around the PICNIC TABLE. As food is passed around, Rachel places a giant FR SALAD on the table in front of Prot.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mark tells me you don't eat meat. I think that's very healthy.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Speak for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So, I made this fruit salad especially for you. Prot just sits there, admiring the beautiful fruit. Then looks at Rachel, with such deep appreciation he does not what to say. His reaction gets to her for a moment, she doesn't know why.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on, take as much as you like. Prot digs in, taking spoonful, after spoonful - after spoonful . Until there is a heaping mountain of it on his plate. As EVERYONE stares. The kids hold their hands over their mouths to not laugh. Prot glances up, gives them all a sm Everyone takes this as a cue to start eating, food is pas around. Dom, putting ketchup on his burger, pauses self- consciously a moment, as he watches Prot shovel in fruit

dialogues.speaker: DOM
dialogues.text: So ~ what do they eat on K-PAX? McAllister gives her husband a kick under the table.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: {mouth full) Krees, likras mainly. But my favorites are our grains, drak, thon and adro - has a nutty flavor much like your cashew.

dialogues.speaker: DOM
dialogues.text: (with an eye to McAllister) Iosee ... Rachel gives Powell a poignant glance. She's never heard anything so outlandish said so convincingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prot, lemonade in hand, walks across the yard, Shasta at his side. WE SEE things through his

dialogues.speaker: WE CUT TO
dialogues.text: a tail-wagging

dialogues.speaker: DARK GLASSES
dialogues.text: now ... almost in moving snapshots ... Abby, pulling a prickler from Gabby's bare foot ... Mrs. Trexler smelling flower ... Dom, giving McAllister a little smooch. Prot absorbs them all, smiling at -everyone as he wanders ... through the open patio doors, and into the HOUSE. McAllister shoots Powell a look. Powell considers a momen then gives her a nod. McAllister follows Prot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prot wanders into Powell's den. Finds FAMILY PHOTOGRAPHS there. Picks one up. It is a PHOTO of Powell' s son, Michael, from a previous marriage. Rachel enters. Finds Prot there

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: There is a picture of a young man -- where your other pictures are. —-

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That's Michael. Mark's son. From first marriage.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: How many marriages has he had?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Just the two, so far.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: So far?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I mean he's not out to set a world record,

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: {with photo) He is not here today? his

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No. He doesn't live with us, you know, he's away at college, and... (beat) Well, the truth is he and Mark don't talk to each other. I don't know why I'm telling you this.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Because I'm a locked-up lunatic, so what could the harm be?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Maybe. Maybe that's it. Prot smiles. Then looks at the photo again and turns sudd reflective...

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Doctor Powell has been trying to teach me this importance you humans place on your "biological connections."

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Do you think he means it?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Do you know what a family is? You worry. They don't tell you that when you decide to leave your single life behind...When they're throwing the rice and dancing the tarantella...That there is no “biological connection” -- not the way you say it, like it's something concrete ~~ like a rope or a ligament. There's just this desperate effort to hold on -- to hold onto them. And when you see someone you love falling away -- falling -- and you can't hold on anymore...

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Then?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: te Hee LE ER EE +t  63 64 Rev. 11/20/00 (Buff) 72.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You don't have a family?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: We don't have families on K-PAX.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Then you don't know what you're missing.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: What? Or who? They exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Let me get you another lemonade. On Prot, as he watches Rachel exit. ‘Then he notices a TELESCOPE in the study. Moves to it. Considers it a momen Then he bends down. Lifts his sunglasses. Squints through the eyepiece. As he does, he lowers his scope. Focusing o something earthbound out the window... And we see that it is Powell, at the far edge of the yard that he has in his sights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Prot walks over to Powell. They stand there together u the trees. Powell takes a sip of beer, Prot noisily slurp his lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Fourth of July. (reminiscing) I remember when Michael was a young boy, I'd take him to the fairground. (another sip of beer, as the memory takes him someplace) We'd spend the evening ... eating apple pie, watching the fireworks. Prot turns his dark glasses to Powell.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Thank you for inviting me here, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You're most welcome, Prot. Just then, Natalie runs up, grabbing Prot's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ca ee  64 Rev. 11/20/00 (Buff) 722B*.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Push me on the swing! As she leads Prot off to the TREE SWING, Powell watches, circumspectly ... as Prot's fingers close so naturally an tenderly around hers. Rachel comes out of the house, also watching ... carefull Prot picks Natalie up, sits her down on the swing. Making sure her hands grip the ropes.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Hold on tight now. He pushes her, gently - playfully - a little higher, now. ducks under the swing - comes back up. Making Natalie lau Her buoyant laughter bringing a big smile to his face. As Prot walks over to Powell. They stand there together u the trees. Pow

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON POWELL ... as he watches, struck, by how familiar Prot with Natalie ... as if he's pushed a swing many times. Just then - Josh dashes out of the house in a bathing sui and turns on the LAWN SPRINKLERS — the water hissing up in jets around the swing ~ The SOUND of it suddenly makes Prot stiffen. He looks around - visibly shaken ~ at the harmless spray of water. hissing taking on an ominous quality. Powell regards Prot, strangely, noticing the change in hi Abby runs after Josh, angrily grabbing his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Why did you do that!? Natalie slides off the swing, gleefully.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Let's run through the water!

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: No ... wait ... He grabs her arn.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: (frightened now) Let go!

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Natalie breaks free, runs for her mother. Around his DARK GLASSES, Prot's face fills with pain and +++ Watching Natalie run off.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: No ... don't go ... He starts after her ...

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Prot! At the same time Powell runs for him, Dom and Danny quick take their cues. They rush Prot, bringing him down. But h struggles like a wild animal. His voice choked and inarticulate, as he keeps trying to reach for Natalie.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Ddddddddd .... Nnmnnnonnn! Gabby watches, horrified, as ... Danny, 180 pounds of varsity wrestler, is flung off. Leav Dom, Powell ~ and now Steve ~ straining to hold Prot down

dialogues.speaker: DOM
dialogues.text: God, he's strong as an ox!

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Betty, quick! McAllister goes for her purse, uncaps a syringe. Mrs. Trexler helps Danny up, viewing Prot with a mixture fear and pity - as the others try and keep him down.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Turn off the goddamn sprinklers! In the struggle, Prot's GLASSES get knocked off. With a m he buries his face in his hands. Abby finally gets the sprinklers off. Rachel clutches Nat Fowell, Dom and Steve stand up, slowly, carefully, drippi wet. Prot remains on his knees, head to the ground. His should shaking. Shasta licks him, whimpering. He gropes on the grass, finding his glasses. Puts them on Then lifts his head, a little isoriented. He gets up, brushes himself off. Bewildered by all the unnerved FACES staring back at him. Natalie, now afraid, hides behind Ra Prot just smiles, sniffs the air -

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: is that apple pie I smell? He walks, unsteadily, towards the picnic table. He sits, serves himself a slice of APPLE PIE. Starts devouring it. Rachel comes up to Powell, angrily.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Happy? I think you got through to him, don't you? I think you made your dent! She throws the towel at him she has just dried Natalie of with, and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leaving Powell standing there. He stares at Prot ... not without excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell paces in front of Villers, at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: -.-He was pushing my daughter on a swing like he'd done it a hundred times before. Not like some alien from K~-PAX. I saw him. He was connecting with something. Some kind of normal ife...

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: That's not enough.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You can't transfer him to the fourth floor. (It'll kill him. Not now -- when I'm actually making some progress with him.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: This is a violent patient.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: He's not violent. I think something violent happened to him. Prot wasn't going after Natalie to harm her. He was trying to protect her.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: From the sprinklers?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I don't know from what.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: I need more to go on than a hunch. Otherwise-—

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: We need to regress him. Take him back into the past. Find out what happened and force him to confront it.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: Hypnotize him? When did you last conduct a hypnosis session? Med school? Do you have any idea how risky it is to regress a patient like this one?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: It’s his only chance.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: Push him too hard and he could wind up switching to an alter or worse.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: He has to be pushed. There's no time. He says he's going back to K-PAX on July 27th. That's three weeks away. I think he could become violent on that day -~ hurt himself or someone else -— ‘

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: You know what the problem is, Mark? You're too close to this patient. Everyone can see it but you. (beat) I'm transferring him to the fourth floor. That's final. Powell thinks a beat.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Then you help me do it.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You were right. What do I know about hypnosis? A six-hour course when I was a resident. You can do this. You're the expert. There's nobody better.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: That's exactly why I won't do it. I've seen what can happen.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Please, Claudia. {beat) That's the whole point of seeing a shrink, isn't it? -- that no matter how crazy or screwed up your world is, at least you're not alone. (off her look) I can't do it on my own -- I'm too close -- fine, I admit it. Doesn't he deserve at least one person on his side.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: Mark, why choose this one to save? He looks at her. It takes him a moment to say this.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Because I feel like maybe...somehow he chose me. On Villers, as she considers a beat,

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. WARD 2 —- MORNING Powell stands in the doorway of PROT'S EMPTY ROOM. Navarr and Simms stand there with him.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What do you mean - he's gone!? Navarro and Simms eye each other, extremely embarrassed, extremely stumped.

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: He's just ... gone. Powell shakes his head, unwilling to hear this. He marche over to a SECURITY MONITOR by the nurse's station, Navarr Simms following on his heels. A SECURITY GUARD is already rewinding the night's surveil video for them. They all watch the MONITOR ... on it, Pro appears walking down the hallway, and into his room.

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: That's around six-thirty, after dinner. He goes in... Powell keeps his eyes glued to Prot's door in the time-st video, as it is fast-forwarded. We SEE what Navarro relay

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: He never comes out. Seven o'clock this morning. He ain't there.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Wait, wait - what was that? Go back.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The security guard rewinds - plays ~ three seconds of STA appear on the screen - then the picture comes back.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Happens sometimes with these old cameras. Or, could be the tape.

dialogues.speaker: NAVARRO
dialogues.text: He just - disappeared. Powell looks at Navarro.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: That's bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: INT, DAY ROOM A67
dialogues.text: He marches into the DAY ROOM, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Has anyone seen Prot!? Sal keeps his eyes on the checkers between him and Ernie.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: He went up north for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: {(squints at him) North ... !? Howie lifts his head, casually, from a book.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Greenland, Iceland, you know. He had a few more countries left to visit, before he could finish his report.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Don't ~ don't worry, Doctor Powell. He'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (peering at Ernie) How do you know? Mrs. Archer gives Powell an obvious smile, over her Japan fan.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. ARCHER
dialogues.text: Because he took his glasses with him, darling. When he returns to K-PAX - he won't need them.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rev. 11/28/00 (Salmon) 7BA*.

dialogues.speaker: A67 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Powell views them all, ludicrously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the bowels of the hospital. It's pitch dark, sav for the beams of several flashlights. Powell, wearing an obsessed expression, plays his beam ov broken Xerox machines and corroding file cabinets. A youn SECURITY GUARD gives him a weary look.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: We've checked every inch of this hospital, Doctor Powell. Nobody ever comes down here. A 2ND BEEFIER SECURITY GUARD, down on his belly, flashes beam into the last corner of the tunnel - illuminating a wall. He looks back at Powell, shaking his head. Powell looks at them both, wipes a cobweb from his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McAllister, Chakraborty, Fleen, the rest of the gang, sea As Villers stares - incredulous ~ at Powell, who stands.

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: Patients don't just escape from this institution. They don't just escape!

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (knowing how bad it sounds) There's no evidence of escape ... but, obviously, I've notified the police, social services. They're taking it as a low priority since he has no clear record of being a public threat ...

dialogues.speaker: VILLERS
dialogues.text: (having heard enough) I'm going to have a great time explaining this to the state board. We have psychotics up on Ward Four packing their sneakers because they think they're all going to K~PAX. Find him, Doctor Powell! Powell nods, there's nothing he'd like better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleary-eyed, Powell sits at his desk, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What about the city shelters? Have you checked ... no ... no, I'm not telling you how to do your job ... thank you. He hangs up, looks through the doorway to his outer offic where Mrs. Trexler still sits. Curiously, he gets up, shirt rumpled, tie loose. He walks over, observing her diligent face - as she scrolls throug windows of lists and information on her COMPUTER.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TREXLER
dialogues.text: Phil's old partner down at the 4th Precinct - who's now a detective -— gave me a password to search their radio lag. (shaking her head) No police reports of anybody fitting Prot's description being picked up.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Joyce, it's eleven o'clock at night and you're still here. I know why I'm still here - but why are you still here? She laughs, as if this were a silly question, eyeing her CALENDAR ... which already says JULY 17.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TREXLER
dialogues.text: Doctor Powell, do you know how long it takes to search a database like this?

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: That doesn't answer my question. She turns from his pointed gaze, back to her computer. Th Pauses, to regard the PHOTO of her HUSBAND on her desk, f

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TREXLER
dialogues.text: The other day ... when Prot came in, he asked me about Phil. (beat, still hard for her) I said ... my husband was killed in the line of duty ten years ago. Prot looked at me with that, you know, alien, curious look. And asked me ... why I still keep a picture of him. (a little quaver in her voice) I told him ... because it reminds me of all the happiness we had together. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TREXLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat, smiles) The next morning there were the most beautiful carnations on my desk. She wipes a tear from her cheek, looks up at Powell, in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TREXLER
dialogues.text: Now how did Prot know those were my favorite flowers? Powell looks at her, not even knowing how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powell, asleep, his head on his desk. A finger of SUNLIGH streams in across the desk ... kisses his face. He squint stirring, wakes up. Realizes he’s been there all night. He sits there a moment. Then, puts his hand into the beam sunlight ... a funny sensation coming over him. He gets up, quickly, follows the BEAM ~ out his office - the HALLWAY. To a window. He peers out - te the hospital grounds, below. Birds chirp in the early morning sun, dew is still on the grass. And on the bench the fountain ... sits a solitary FIGURE. Powell can tell from the back - that it is Prot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Powell, tie loose, suit wrinkled, hair disheveled, rac across the grounds to Prot, who hears him coming up, behi

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Doctor Powell, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Where the hell have you been!?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Newfoundland, Labrador, Greenland, Iceland -

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Cut the crap! We've been searching for you for three days! Prot regards Powell, not a little put off by his attitude

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I believe I mentioned my taking a trip up north in one of our sessions, Mark. You really should keep track.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Taking a trip!? (looks around, with a mad laugh, then back to Prot) You're a patient here! You don't get out of here without a discharge. Nobody does! Nobody has, nobody ever will! And don't, don't give me that beam of light shit. Because I don't buy it! Prot shifts his glasses away, somewhat confused and distu As Powell sits down next to him. Powell's eyes remain, intently, on him.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What would you say - if I were to tell you that I don't believe you took any trip to Iceland, Greenland, or any Place? That I don't believe you're from K-PAX. That I believe you are as human as I am.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I would say you were in need of a thorazine drip, Doctor. Powell walked right into that one.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Then, I appeal to your intelligence. Can't you at least admit the possibility that I MIgGHt be right?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I will admit the possibility. If you will admit the possibility that I am from K-PAX. Powell realizes, at this moment, just how much this "bein has gotten under his skin. It is also, at this moment, he senses his opportunity:

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Well, there is ... one way you could convince me beyond any doubt. Of course, I'd need your consent.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Prot's glasses meet Powell's eyes, unsurely.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: It's called hypnosis. It's more like --

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: i'm familiar with the term, Mark. After all, I have read most of your medical books during my time here. (beat, resistant) i do not see the point.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Well, let me tell you what your alternative is. A trip to a place where they'll stick a needle in your ass every morning, which may ~ or may not ~ leave you with a stupid grin on your face for the rest of your days here on Earth. Is that what you'd like? Because - believe me - I'll be sorced to sign a transfer before July th! For a long moment, Prot is silent. He looks, disquietly, at the birds and the trees and the high brick wall. Powell's voice becomes gentle, earnest.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I want to help you, Prot.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: {smiles) You have. You've provided me with a place to stay while I write my report. You've fed me. The fruit is wonderful --

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: I don't mean that kind of help. The resistance on Prot's brow begins to cave, as he strug with Powell's request.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Let me help you, Prot. A long beat. Prot brings his eyes back to Powell. 83. 71 eee ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee ee RE + oF  71 Al2 72 Rev. 01/09/01 (Ivory)

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Nobody needs. Nobody wants. Nobody on K-PAX misses me -~ there would be no reason to. But when I leave here, I will be missed. (beat) A strange feeling.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: You don't have to leave, Prot. I'm sure there must be some way for me to help you... {off Prot's look) »..to stay. As one of us. Prot looks at Powell. Squeezes his knee.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: I'll miss you, Doctor Powell. 83A. 71 Prot exits. On Powell, as he watches Prot enter the hospi

dialogues.speaker: A72

dialogues.text: Windowless, subdued lighting. Prot is reclined ina specia CHAIR. His dark glasses rest on his lap. A wire monitor i patched to one wrist, and another to his chest, beneath h shirt. Despite this, he looks comfortable. More so than Powell, who, wearing a tiny EARPHONE, sits f him. Nevertheless, Powell keeps his voice calm.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What we're going to be doing, Prot, is kind of like ~ daydreaming. When you daydream - you go into a natural trance. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chakraborty, wearing headphones with a mouthpiece, sits a heart and pulse MONITOR. A pulse rate beeps on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Windowless, subdued lighting. Prot is reclined in a speci CHAIR. His dark glasses rest on his lap. A wire monitor i patched to one wrist, and another to his chest, beneath h shirt. Despite this, he looks comfortable, More so than Powell, who, wearing a tiny EARPHONE, sits f him. Wevertheless, Powell keeps his voice calm.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: What we're going to be doing, Prot, is kind of like - daydreaming. When you daydream - you go into a natural trance, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're just going to help induce that trance. Kind of daydream together. Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: When you are.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Good. I want you to keep your arms at your sides and your legs uncrossed. Focus your attention on the white spot in front of you. Do you see it? Prot locks at the bright CIRCLE on the otherwise bare wal

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Of course ...

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Good ... IT want you to keep your eyes on that spot ... don't take your eyes off of it. You don't have to use any effort to keep focused on that spot «.. it's easy ... so just relax, keep your eyes on that spot ... and keep listening to my voice ... Do you understand? Prot's clear, dark eyes are fixed on the white circle. Hi voice getting more relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: Mark, you are talking to a K-PAXIAN ...

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (smiles) I'm going to count from one to five. At the count of three your eyes will close and you will find yourself ina very nice, deep, comfortable, relaxed state of hypnosis. One, your eyes are starting to feel heavy now. Two, want you to use your imagination. Imagine small lead weights on your eyelids making them heavier and heavier. Three, keep your eyes closed and let yourself go way, way down leep. Prot's breathing becomes deeper, eyelids getting droopy, beginning to tilt ...

What you don't know...is that...when the Universe expands again, everything will be as it was before. Whatever mistakes you make this time around, you will live through again on the next pass. dialogues.text: With a smile, he holds up a PHOTOGRAPH to Porter. Porter' eyes move, slowly, to the smiling picture of Howie and Er But he registers no reaction. Powell takes it back, tries to keep a smile. He goes back reading the letter --

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Say hello to all my friends ... I miss them. And please let me know when Bess comes back because I want to know all about K - He stops himself. Reflective a moment. Glances at Porter, troubling. Then, just folds up the letter, puts it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: That's one thing we need to talk about Bess. z Really worried about Bess. We've checked shelters, halfway homes, the police have come up empty ... it's as if she ... just disappeared. (looks cannily at Robert) July twenty-seventh. You wouldn't happen to want to tell me anything about that, would you, Robert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's searching Porter's expressionless EYES.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: No? (with an earnest smile) Well, maybe it'll come to you. Whenever you're ready. I'll be waiting. He gets up, gives Porter a pat on the shoulders. And take the handles of the wheelchair. Pushing Porter on, along t path, through the park.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Doctor, patient. Curious human distinction ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE TAKE IN THE DAY ROOM. As Maria gazes out a window. And Russell mumbles to himself, Bible in hand. And Sal and Mrs. Archer play a contentious game of fish.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: By his own calculations, he is due again soon. WE MOVE ON ... into the ART ROOM. Where Navarro, setting new patient down at some watercolors, pauses, respectfull to look at PROT'S GLASSES, which rest on a pedestal, like shrine, facing the window.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: The patients in Ward Two have no doubts whatsoever, nor some of the staff ... AND WE LOOK OUT THROUGH THOSE DARK GLASSES ... into the dancing sunlight ...

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As for me ... well ... maybe Prot left me Robert Porter.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And a couple of other tasks. (ALT) INT. WARD 2 - ART ROOM — DAY Powell walks, slowly ... toward PROT'S SUNGLASSES, which on a pedestal, like’ a shrine, with a "Do Not Disturb, Be Soon" sign. They face the window. Powell stares at them for a long beat. Then, looking around, seeing no one else is there, he ben down ... to LOOK THROUGH THEM ... And as he does, WE SEE THROUGH THEM ... into the dancing sunlight ... the SUNGLASS LENSES NOW FILLING THE SCREEN . and the pinpoints of sunlight playing like a thousand twinkling stars ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND WE ARE BACK with the OUT-OF-FocUS CROWDS of Grand Cen Station ... the FIGURES resolve into PEOPLE, rushing here there ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: te et Al42  Rev. 07/17/01 (2nd Buff) (Replacement Scenes) 128%. Al42 CONTINUED: Al42 And now CLOSE ON POWELL, standing with his briefcase, * searching for someone in the crowds ... * We hear Prot, 0.8. *

dialogues.speaker: PROT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mark ... we KPAXians have been around * long enough to have discovered a * little something about the origins of * the Universe that you don't know yet. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I'll tell you. Powell moves his eyes over the nameless faces, more inten searching ... *

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: The Universe will expand, then * collapse back on itself -- then expand * again. It will repeat this process * again and again, forever. What you * don't know ... is that ... when the * Universe expands again, everything * will be as it was before. Whatever * mistakes you make this time around, * you will live through again. Over and * over, forever. * A smile seizes Powell, as he's found who he's searching f

dialogues.speaker: PROT
dialogues.text: So, my advice to you is to get it * right this time around. Because ... * this time ... is all you have. * And WE SEE MICHAEL. Coming out of a gate, duffle bag over shoulder. Pierced eyebrow. He looks around, unsurely. Unt he spies his father. He smiles, tentative. * They approach each other, through the CROWDS. Stand there facing each other. Powell initiates a hug, halting at fir then warm, gripping his son around the shoulders. * And as the CAMERA PULLS BACK ... they walk off together, through a SHAFT OF SUNLIGHT streaming down from one of th high, station windows ... and on ... to the Metro North * gates ... *
